title: Organizational Structures
description: Learn how organizational structure affects project manager authority and team dynamics.
objectives: Compare functional, matrix, and projectized organizational structures
Understand PM authority levels in each structure
Identify how structure impacts resource availability and team dynamics

screens.headline: Who Does Alex Report To?

visual.scenario: Alex needs Maya for the project, but Maya's manager (Head Chef) won't release her. Carlos says 'figure it out.' Elena says 'not my problem.' WHO has authority?

dialogue.text: I need Maya full-time on the expansion project, but her manager won't release her from kitchen duties. Carlos says I'm the PM so I should 'just make it happen.' But I don't have authority over Maya's schedule. Who do I escalate to?

screens.learningHook: Your authority as a PM depends on your organization's STRUCTURE. In some structures, you have full control. In others, you must negotiate for every resource.

screens.title: Organizational Structure Assessment
screens.instructions: Identify the organizational structure in each scenario and predict the PM's authority level.

scenarios.title: Scenario 1: Tech Startup
scenarios.description: Project teams are formed for each product launch. Team members report ONLY to the PM. Resources are dedicated full-time. The PM controls budget, assignments, and performance reviews.

questions.question: What is the PM's authority level?

scenarios.title: Scenario 2: Traditional Bank
scenarios.description: Staff work in departments (IT, Marketing, Operations). Projects are managed BY department heads. A 'PM' coordinates but has no authority—must request resources from each department. Staff loyalty is to their department, not the project.

questions.question: What is the PM's authority level?

scenarios.title: Scenario 3: Savory & Co. (Current State)
scenarios.description: Staff have functional managers (Head Chef, FOH Manager) but also work on projects. Alex manages the expansion project but must negotiate with functional managers for resources. Staff split time between daily operations and project work.

questions.question: What challenge does Alex face in this structure?

options.text: Resources split between functional duties and project work

structures.name: Functional
structures.description: Staff grouped by specialty (Marketing, IT, Operations). Department heads control resources.
structures.pmAuthority: Little or none—PM coordinates, doesn't control

structures.name: Matrix
structures.description: Staff report to BOTH functional manager AND PM. Shared control over resources.
structures.pmAuthority: Low to moderate—negotiates with functional managers

structures.name: Projectized
structures.description: Staff dedicated to projects. PM has full control over team.
structures.pmAuthority: High to total—PM controls resources, budget, assignments

characteristics: Staff loyalty to department, not projects
content.pmChallenge: Getting resources requires approval from department heads who have competing priorities.

types.name: Weak Matrix
types.characteristic: PM is part-time, functional manager dominates

types.name: Balanced Matrix
types.characteristic: PM and functional manager share authority

types.name: Strong Matrix
types.characteristic: PM has more authority than functional manager

content.pmChallenge: Dual reporting—staff may receive conflicting priorities from PM and functional manager.
disadvantages: Conflict between PM and functional manager

characteristics: PM has full authority over team
content.pmAuthority: High to total—controls budget, assignments, performance reviews

strategies.strategy: Build relationships with department heads. Frame requests in terms of departmental benefit. Use sponsor escalation when stuck.
Negotiate resource agreements upfront. Clarify priorities with functional managers. Communicate conflicts early.
Use authority responsibly. Build team culture. Plan for staff transition after project ends.

content.insight: Your authority is GIVEN by the structure. Your effectiveness is EARNED through leadership and influence—regardless of structure.

screens.title: Applying Structure Knowledge
screens.context: Alex needs Maya full-time for the expansion, but Maya reports to the Head Chef who won't release her.

questions.question: Given Savory & Co.'s matrix structure, what should Alex do?

options.text: Directly order Maya to leave kitchen duties (PM authority)
Negotiate with Head Chef, involve Carlos if needed (matrix approach)
Give up and find a different resource
Wait until Head Chef releases Maya voluntarily

questions.question: Build Your Negotiation Message
questions.instruction: Complete the negotiation message to Sam (Marketing Director) about Nina's allocation.
questions.sentence: Hi Sam, I understand Nina is [________]—that's a critical priority. For the rollout, I need [________] for location-specific marketing. You've offered 5 hrs/week, which is [________]. Can we discuss options? (1) [________], (2) [________], or (3) [________]. What works best for your team?

correctAnswers: fully allocated to the flagship campaign
Assign a junior marketer to support
Delay rollout to sequence after flagship

wordBank.text: fully allocated to the flagship campaign
Assign a junior marketer to support
Delay rollout to sequence after flagship
Take Nina full-time for my project

feedback.high: Excellent negotiation! You acknowledged Sam's priorities, quantified the gap, and proposed collaborative solutions—classic matrix negotiation.
feedback.low: Remember the negotiation framework: (1) Acknowledge their priorities, (2) Explain your need, (3) Quantify the gap, (4) Propose options, (5) Invite collaboration.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: Your PM authority depends on organizational structure. Adapt your approach based on where you work.
takeaways: FUNCTIONAL: PM coordinates, little authority. Build department relationships.
MATRIX: Shared authority. Negotiate with functional managers. Clarify priorities.
PROJECTIZED: Full authority. Use it responsibly. Build team culture.
Most organizations are MATRIX—master negotiation and influence skills
Structure defines authority. Leadership defines effectiveness.

artifacts.title: Matrix Navigation Guide
artifacts.description: How to work with dual reporting

characterClosing.text: Alex, now you understand WHY getting Maya was difficult. In a matrix, you negotiate—not command. Master influence skills and you'll succeed in any structure.

nextLesson.teaser: You understand your authority. Now master the triple constraint—balancing scope, time, cost, and quality.
